nodes.bodyText: Thought we weren't using aliases for lang libs in examples?

We weren't?
Did a quick search for "import ballerina/lang" and we seem to be using aliases in all the examples?
The expression itself is is a binary expression
The spec mentions these as bitwise-and-expr, bitwise-or-expr, etc. Hence used the same.

Then shall we first properly define what we mean by "bitwise AND expression" etc.? Because when referring to AND or &, what we immediately think of is the operator. The term "bitwise AND expression" sounds a bit alien.

Any suggestions? Wanted to highlight the & operator along with AND.
Do we need to "define" what a "bitwise AND expression" is? IMO, it's clear even though the terms aren't familiar.
I'm ok with using the term bitwise AND expression. But using & within parenthesis like here is kinda misleading. It's why I assumed you meant the & operator when I first saw this.
No need for a lengthy definition. Can expand the description you've given in the .description file to make it clear what a bitwise AND expression is

Can you recheck after the changes btw.
I've said
For a bitwise "AND" (&) expression,
emphasizing "AND" and the having the operator within parentheses. Is it still not clear?
Same comment as above re: referencing to bitwise AND as an expression. Can see in other places too
The second sentence is not exactly clear. Do you mean that the vacated bit positions are filled using 0?

This again is from the spec. Do we need to mention something like "vacated".
We just shift the bits to the left, adding in 0s at the right. We don't have to go into details about how shift works right?
Yeah, I noticed the definition in the spec later. The thing was, it took me a little while to get what it meant. Isn't there an easier/clearer way to say it?

IMO, saying "bits shifted to the right" kinda implies that the existing bits are shifted to the right. But that is not the case.
The existing bits are shifted to the left, while 0s are shifted in from the right.
